repnme.cdata!:
Energy reforms in Armenia - On the way to
            energy security

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about energy
            reforms in Armenia. The development of renewable energy in
            Armenia was of triple importance. Firstly, it used local
            energy sources, secondly it used renewable energy sources
            and thirdly, it used clean sources of energy. Armenia
            Renewable Energy Project designed the scheme for small
            hydropower stations, and developed model business plans and
            guidelines for the renewable energy sector. Ninety Two
            hydropower stations were constructed under the project which
            would meet six percent of the internal demand for
            electricity. Besides providing electricity, small hydropower
            stations also provided jobs.

docna.cdata!:
Energy reforms in Armenia - On the way to
            energy security

display_title.display_title:
Energy reforms in Armenia - On
            the way to energy security

repnme.cdata!:
Promoting safe and clean heating and
            increasing renewable energy generation in Armenia

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            promoting safe and clean heating, and increasing renewable
            energy generation in Armenia. Around 36 percent of residents
            of multi-apartment buildings relied on wood, household waste
            and other polluting fuels for heating, which were
            detrimental for health and the environment. The modern
            heater and gas connection costs were prohibitively high. Due
            to the lack of appropriate heating, many schools did not
            function during the winter months. World Bank supported
            Armenia by funding Urban Energy Project which focused on the
            use of safe, clean and affordable heating, and renewable
            energy generation. The World Bank energy program supported
            the government in improving the power transmission network
            infrastructure and reducing power supply gap.

12826100.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
12826100.theme: Other Financial Sector Development,Climate change,Other Private Sector Development
12826100.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The closing date for Armenia Renewable
            Energy Project will be extended from December 31, 2010 until
            June 30, 2011. The actual project outcome indicators for
            renewable generation and carbon dioxide emissions have
            exceeded the target indicators from the first year of the
            project implementation till present. The implementation of
            the International Development Association (IDA)-financed
            on-lending component is essentially completed and the
            funding is almost fully disbursed. The implementation of
            some activities under the Global Environment Facility (GEF)
            grant-financed technical assistance component has been slow;
            however, the procurement of these activities has already
            started and the task team, based on the latest procurement
            plan, estimates that these studies will be completed by June
            30, 2011. The extension is necessary to complete some key
            studies - update of the feasibility study of Loriberd hydro
            power plant, development of innovative financing instruments
            for the development of renewable energy projects,
            preparation of the roadmap for the development of renewable
            resources - under the technical assistance component of the project.

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Renewable Energy
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
